The fitter says I am just not use to these things and need to gradually build up time of wearing them. The second day the sleeve went on a lot easier and has wrinkle by inside of elbow. After washing and drying it is very hard to get on again. So does it have to be that tight because it loosens so much Is one wrinkle by elbow inside normal? Is hand swelling from the wrist being so tight? Has anyone had thumb go numb and stretched thumb out by wetting and putting over top of a water bottle or something? Is gauntlet suppose to lay flat across inside of hand? At top of arm where sleeve ends how tight is right? Do you have the spots from the band that holds it up on arm for a long time after taking off?  Thank you! Posts.Title: Drains raysnbucs Moderators

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2013 05:59PM vaper wrote: AmyQ, Thank you for posting! Every week the nurse kept saying wear the compression bandage a few more days. My skin was getting sore in a couple places. My nurse friend said she thought it had been long enough, so I went with out it yesterday, by this morning I had swelling, and pain! I put the ace bandage back on. I have worn it all day, but the swelling has not gone down, maybe up more. :( I have a appointment with the oncologist tomorrow. I will see what she thinks. tangandchri, I know dear, the drain is so aggravating! after 2 months I finely got mine out, but I still worry that I might get or have a seroma down in there that is going to cause some horrible complication. I was not given a compression garment or even a ace bandage at the hospital. Many people have told me they were sent home from the hospital with them. After my drainage was still high a month later a nurse wrapped me in a Ace bandage. I was given a prescription before surgery for 2 camisoles with pockets for the drain bulb, they do not compress, or support anything in any way at all! Insurance (Medicare) paid 80% for them. I only wore them a couple times. They were to hot and uncomfortable, they rubbed under my arm where my incision from lymph nodes were removed. I ended up just pinning the tab of the bulb to my night gown or shirt. You might want to see if your insurance covers the camisoles, if you do not get hot easily. (If I was able to drive and you needed big ones, I would send you mine! I got 2 different brands and sizes. They run big.) My swelling under my arm, even behind it was a lot! I still have a lot of extra fat, skin, etc. there. The nurse says it is just my body, but my other (non surgery) side does not have all that extra! I know what you mean about looking SO disfigured! I was so worried about possible infections and other things it did not really set in until recently! sandra4611, I agree! I got my drain out finely 2 weeks ago. I am still worried about a seroma down in there!

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2013 11:59AM vaper wrote: I had an appointment with a nurse practitioner yesterday. She had me see a skin care nurse who put a bandaid type sealant over the rash. She thinks it is not infected because it did not respond to antibiotic or yeast ointments. They think it is the tube rubbing on skin causing the rash. I go back to see them Monday. I had a allergic reaction to the oral antibiotic, they did not start me on another one. They do not think there is infection in my surgery site. I wish there was a way of knowing for sure! My drainage still goes up and down, went from yellow for weeks back to orange for a week meaning blood in there again. Then yesterday is was yellow, but back to orange today! They say that is ok. The nurses said I might still have drainage because I might have a seroma, (a pocket of fluid) that could get infected and turn into a big problem, so they wrapped my chest in ace bandages. They are not comfortable of course, but I have been able to keep them on so far. They want them to only come off for cleaning. Of course if I take them off I would not be able to get back on, and my nurse friend is busy with all kinds of other activities, and the nurses said that home health care would not come for this or anything! They keep telling me to not do any thing active. I keep telling them I live alone and have to! The NP says Monday she will make sure my surgeon sees me. I know he will not be happy, praying for wisdom for all of us! Thank you everyone for your help!

Posts.Content: vaper wrote: The Oncologists thought it was bacteria, it was just a tiny spot so she said put antibiotic cream on it. It got bigger, about the size of a dime over the weekend. So I called the surgeons office. I saw the nurse and PA. They thought it was yeast/fungal and said use Nystatin. Before I got home it had grown to the size of about a quarter.  The Nystatin has not  helped and now part of the area is dark like purple. I called nurse, she talked to PA who called in a prescription for ceflex and wants me to see a NP Monday. They are not concerned because my temperature has gone up a little, but   not much. (mine is usually 97, it is 99) I know if it is MRSA it can get bad quick. I am worried!
